newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks pare losses at close on late buying.
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks pare losses at close on late buying.

text.p: Mexican stocks pared losses in late trade to close almost flat on Friday as dealers rushed to buy stocks to close their books for the week, traders said.
"At the close they tried to jack some prices up before the weekend, others bought ahead of forthcoming earnings reports," a trader from the Bancomer brokerage said.
The leading IPC share index ended down 0.32 point, or 0.01 percent, at 3,654.34. Volume was moderate at 78.3 million shares traded.
Analysts noted that volume was thin and the market shrugged off the rally on Wall Street.
"The market was listless and quite overlooked developments in New York. Dealers are waiting for Q4 earnings reports in order to reshuffle portfolios," an analyst from the Arka brokerage said.
In contrast to the bourse's lackluster performance, Dow industrials surged 1.22 percent to close at 6,855.80 points.
Traders said January inflation figures released in late trade had little effect on market sentiment.
"We already knew it would be high and it was within expectations. The important thing is to see whether it goes down next month," an analyst from the Finamex brokerage said.
"Dealers were apathetic, they barely took any notice of the inflation figures," a floor trader added.
Banco de Mexico announced that consumer prices rose 2.57 percent in January, compared with 3.20 percent in December.
A Reuters survey MXAAP of nine financial houses in Mexico City had predicted an average figure of 2.4 percent.
A total of 112 stocks changed hands on the broad market scoreboard, of which 40 ended up while 39 were down.
Heaviest traded stock at the head of the gainers' list .PG.MX was food company Herdez, whose A shares gained 12 centavos to 3.02 pesos.
Herdez B shares, meanwhile, gained 11 centavos to 3.03 pesos. Dealers noted the Bear Stearns brokerage announced during trade it had initiated coverage of the company with an attractive rating.
Traders noted the presence of steeltube maker Tamsa at the top of the decliners' list .PL.MX after falling 3.50 pesos to 127.50 pesos.
"Tamsa just had to fall after climbing for several months," one dealer said.
